BACKGROUND AND GOVERNMENT STRATEGY 1.1 Iodine deficiency disorder (IDD), which occurs in all provinces of Indonesia, is a significant and preventable risk factor affecting the quality of human resources. Its most important effects are increased neonatal and infant mortality and reduced mental ability. As such it can be an important factor limiting educational achievement and economic development. 1.2 Although iodine deficiency has been recognized in Indonesia since the 1 920s, it was not until the 1980s that information was collected on a national scale in an attempt to determine the full extent of the problem. Based on this information it was believed that approximately one-sixth of the population was at risk of iodine deficiency. However, recent analysis by a GOI/Bank team indicates that the size of the population at risk is much larger than was previously thought.' At least a third, and possibly as much as one half of the population of Indonesia is at risk of iodine deficiency2. The methodological limitations and age of the previous survey mean that it is unsuitable as the basis for targeting programs or for use as a baseline against which to measure change. Further, there is a clear indication that control efforts to date have not been successful. Recognizing these limitations and the importance of iodine deficiency the GOI requested the Bank to collaborate in the development of a project to strengthen its efforts to prevent iodine deficiency. A. ECONOMIC AND WELFARE IMPLICATIONS 1.3 The effects of iodine deficiency on human health and welfare can vary in severity. Still birth and perinatal mortality rates are higher in iodine deficient areas. Deficiency in the first three months of pregnancy increases the proportion of cretinous births. Whilst the importance of cretinism, a syndrome characterized by severe retardation of mental and motor development, for the functioning of the individual is obvious, of much broader importance is the evidence that even noncretinous children born in areas where iodine deficiency is endemic may be mentally and neurologically handicapped. Although this impairment, which is thought to be irreversible, may be mild, because it effects a much larger proportion of the population it has important implications for the social and economic development of these communities. Finally, recent studies in several countries have indicated there may also be a component of mild mental retardation which is reversible when iodine is given to children of school age. 1.4 Thus, the effects of iodine deficiency are diverse, ranging from increased mortality through severe disability to milder levels of impairment. There are difficulties in combining all these sequelae in a single index of the effect of iodine deficiency on the community. One approach is to Heywood and Jus'at (1995). 2 A population living in an area in which the prevalence of goiter is at least 10% is "at risk" of iodine deficiency.

In the case of iodine deficiency, the effects will occur through limiting the returns on investment in education, premature mortality, mild and severe levels of disability in adults and the resulting loss in productivity and wages, decreased inventiveness and lower levels of risk taking and investment. The extent of these economic effects will depend on the extent and severity of iodine deficiency, the quality of schooling available and the complexity and novelty of the tasks required of the adults as economic development proceeds. B. EFFORTS TO CONTROL IODINE DEFICIENCY 1.6 As in many other Asian countries, a national IDD control program was initiated in the mid- 1970s with UNICEF support, and iodization of salt was initially seen as the main strategy. However, the difficulties in establishing and monitoring iodization led to an early emphasis on injections of iodized oil as a short term measure. Subsequent international pressure to reach unrealistic targets resulted in continuing reliance on injected oil and a reduction in emphasis, until recently, on salt. 1.7 Iodized oil injections. Over the last 20 years the most sustained efforts to control iodine deficiency have been through the use of iodized oil by the Ministry of Health (MOH). Unfortunately, the effect of 20 years of iodized oil injections has been limited. The recent evaluation of the IDD control program (Heywood and Jus'at, 1995) indicated that, based on Ministry of Health records, the number of injections delivered since 1974 had kept pace with the increase in population but had not
 3 reduced the proportion of the population at risk. By the time iodized oil injections were phased out they were still covering only approximately 7 per cent of the target population. Thus, it has become increasingly clear that continued reliance on iodized oil injections as the primary means of control is not feasible due to problems in the delivery and targeting of injections, the high cost of untargeted delivery and the role of reuse of needles in transmission of hepatitis B and HIV. 1.8 Iodized oil capsules. These concerns resulted in a decision to change, in 1992, from injections to iodized oil in capsules (which provide protection for approximately 1 year, as compared to 4 years for injected oil). Thus, to maintain the same amount of coverage as was provided by injections it is necessary to administer 4 times as many capsules. In addition, based on the revised estimates of the size of the population "at risk" it will be necessary to provide capsules to a much larger population each year. Given the difficulties in administering a much smaller number of injections it is unlikely that these much higher targets will be able to be met. As with injections, the sustainability of a control program based on capsules is low as the cost-effectiveness continues to be limited by low coverage and lack of information for targeting while recurrent costs remain high. MOH records of injections and capsules distributed in recent years indicate that the maximum proportion of the target population covered by injections is approximately 7 per cent and for capsules less than 4 per cent. Clearly the effectiveness of these efforts has been low. 1.9 However, it is important that the unsatisfactory experience to date with capsules in Indonesia does not preclude consideration of the most effective manner in which they might be used. Internationally, the most cost-effective use of capsules (and injections before them) has been in meeting highly specific objectives. For example, capsules have proved very cost-effective when targeted to women of child bearing age in isolated situations where iodine deficiency was severe. By the use of such specific targeting the capsules were being used solely to prevent cretinism (by ensuring that women of childbearing age were iodine replete before conception) in areas where the deficiency was severe (and the probability of a pregnancy resulting in a severely disabled child raised proportionally) and in which other methods of control, such as iodized salt, had limited application for logistic reasons. Under these circumstances capsules are highly effective in achieving a specific outcome - elimination of cretinism. In contrast to this scenario, the use of both capsules and injections in Indonesia has not, in practice, been targeted according to any of these criteria. Consequently, their effectiveness has been very limited. 1.10 Iodized salt. Fortunately there is another method of delivering iodine to the community - iodized salt. It was first tried in Indonesia in the 1920s, faltered after 1945 and was tried again beginning in the mid-1970s. It still has much potential, particularly in light of the evidence from other countries (Levin et al, 1993) of the much greater cost-effectiveness and coverage of this mode of delivering iodine to the community and the recent evidence that the proportion of the Indonesian population at risk of deficiency is much higher than previously thought (see Annex 1). 1.11 However, both the supply of, and demand for, iodized salt are limited and will need to be improved if iodized salt is to be used as the vehicle for distributing iodine to the community. Recent SUSENAS findings indicate that less than 60% of the salt consumed at the household level is iodized to adequate levels and that one-fifth has no iodine at all. The levels of adequacy are lowest in the major producing provinces (East, Central and West Java) and in the eastern part of the country.

Approximately one-fifth of those who did know about iodized salt did not consume it. These results are summarized in Table 1.2. There are no systematic surveys of the price differences across the country. However, information from the salt industry study conducted during project preparation (CTS, 1995; CTS, 1996) indicates that in general iodized salt is 2-3 times the price of uniodized salt. The price difference is driven by the availability of low quality raw salt, the high cost of processing a low quality product, and the costs of iodization and packaging. Compared to the costs of processing and packaging, those for iodization are small. In addition, as part of the effort to improve the supply of iodized salt, one province has given monopoly rights for iodized salt to PT Garam. While the supply of iodized salt has improved, the price is high due to lack of competition. The salt industry 1.14 The salt industry itself is a cardinal factor limiting the supply of, and demand for, iodized salt. By the end of the 1980s, the industry had a number of characteristics similar to those for other highly regulated "essential" commodities in Indonesia, including fertilizer and cement. These included (1) informal marketing arrangements; (2) protection from tariffs; (3) a range of non-tariff steps and barriers restricting free entry and trade in the domestic market; (4) technological stagnation in a technically inefficient industry; and (5) inability to enforce government regulations relating to iodization. (However, unlike fertilizer and cement, the government depends on salt as a component of an important public health program). There was also a floor price for "People's salt" (salt produced by small sharefarmers) operated by PT Garam, the government-owned salt producer and processor, which was the dominant player in the industry. The result of this floor price was a rapid increase in the area of land devoted to People's salt; overproduction of low quality salt; and large national stocks of salt held in conjunction with the price support scheme. The overall result was a low quality, high cost product and very inadequate levels of iodization and consumption of iodized salt, partly as a result of the wide difference in price between raw salt and the processed, iodized and packaged product.
 5 C. INCREASING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF IODIZED SALT 1.15 Increasing supply. The main obstacles to improving the supply and consumption of iodized salt are the low quality of the salt produced, and inadequate monitoring of iodine content of salt and enforcement of regulations. These issues are discussed in detail in Annex 2. a. Low quality of salt. The quality of salt produced in Indonesia is low, a reflection of the low level of technology used by salt farmer/sharefarmers and PT Garam. Improving the quality of salt produced is an important aspect of sustainable improvement in iodization and requires changing the production techniques used by salt farmers/sharefarmers. Within the industry there is little expertise on improved methods of salt production. b. Monitoring the iodine content of salt is inadequate and regulations mandating iodization of salt for human consumption are seldom enforced. Although responsibility for monitoring and enforcement rests with both the MOIT and the MOH, the ability to enforce regulations via cancellation of licenses lies with the MOIT. Resources for monitoring in both ministries have been inadequate and this has hindered identification of those processors who persistently fail to produce adequately iodized salt. As part of this effort, it is vital that the government's own salt company, PT Garam, ensures that its own salt production is iodized. 1.16 Increasing demand for iodized salt. There is considerable potential to increase awareness of the effects of iodine deficiency and the role of iodized salt in their control. The need now is for a general campaign combined with targeted additional efforts to increase consumption in those areas in which iodine deficiency is severe. This needs to be coordinated with efforts to increase the availability and affordability of iodized salt. 1.17 Effect of recent developments in the salt industry. In addition, a number of recent developments in the industry have implications for reliance on salt as the primary vehicle for delivery of iodine to the community. 1.18 Elimination of the floor price for salt and the national stock of salt has resulted in a sharp drop in the farmgate price of salt from approximately 30 Rp/kg in 1993 to 15 Rp/kg in 1995. It is likely that prices will continue at this much lower level, because the earlier floor price was too high and the new entrants attracted by it resulted in excess capacity; and PT Garam is still seeking to sell the remainder of the national stock. 1.19 Falling returns to salt production will force change in the industry and provide an important opportunity for assisting salt farmers/sharefarmers to improve their circumstances through a range of strategies. For those able to survive in a more competitive environment these include technological innovation, improved management of individual farms, consolidation where feasible and, for some, complementary production of other commodities (see Annex 2). Other farmers/sharefarmers are more likely to survive by moving out of salt altogether and concentrating on alternate commodities of which fish and artemia are the best prospects. The overall effect will be increased quality and a reduction in the chronic surplus of salt. 1.20 The most recent attempt by the government to improve iodization of salt is a new set of regulations introduced under the Presidential Decree (Kepres) 69/1994. The decree sets out new
 6 requirements for the industry with particular emphasis on processing. Many of the smaller processors will not be able to meet the new requirements and will not be licensed. Preliminary indications are that the number of processors will be reduced from approximately 300 in 1995 to around 70 in 1997 with the smaller operators dropping out. It is likely that the number will fall even further in the first 2-3 years of the regulations as other smaller firms persistently fail to meet the standards for iodized salt. The final number may be as low as 50. As a result, monitoring the iodine content of salt will be easier. 1.21 PT Garam, the government-owned company, is responsible for 25 percent of domestic production. As a result of its dominance as a producer and advantage in several provinces as a result of restrictive licenses, it holds a privileged position in the industry. And there are now plans for it to purchase and wash 300,000 tons of people's salt per annum as a joint venture with a commercial partner. This has been financed, at least in part, by a soft loan from the government, partly in support of efforts to improve the iodization of salt. The overall effect of this move on the salt industry is unclear. Despite the privileged position it now occupies, the company iodizes only 10 percent of the salt it produces for human consumption. It is critical that, by June 30, 1998, PT Garam iodizes all the salt it produces and/or processes for human consumption (assurances to this effect were received during negotiations). 1.22 The dominance of PT Garam and its inefficiency (see Annex 1) mean that it is a price leader in many parts of the country, in effect allowing salt prices to remain higher than they would in a more competitive setting. It is important PT Garam operates on a commercial basis, forcing it to compete with other producers and become more efficient. 1.23 Government moves to deregulate the economy are also effecting salt. As part of the recent deregulation package announced in June 1996, tariff on salt for human consumption decreased from 25 percent to 20 percent and are scheduled to fall to 10 percent by 2003. 1.24 New players are entering the market. One international salt firm has established a joint venture with an Indonesian partner and other firms are considering entering the market. 1.25 The overall effect of these changes is unclear. Some, such as the reduction in the number of processors and the increased dominance of PT Garam, will decrease competitive pressures. Others, particularly tariff decreases, the entrance of new players, and enforcement of the regulations on iodization of salt, will increase competition. It is critical that overall policy is set to increase competition and ensure that the playing field is level. In this respect, a more rapid reduction in tariffs, and elimination of remaining non-tariff barriers in several provinces would all quicken the move to a competitive industry. At the same time it is vital that the government resists any pressures to reintroduce a floor price and national stock of salt. 1.26 In summary, the Indonesian experience in controlling iodine deficiency confirms the limitations of injections and capsules - both are expensive, their coverage has consistently been very low and their overall effect on iodine deficiency very limited. An important factor contributing to this limited impact is the lack of information which would allow efforts to be directed to those areas which are most deficient in iodine and their effects to be evaluated. At the same time, even though it could be the most cost-effective and sustainable method of delivering iodine to the community, salt has not fulfilled its potential. Less than 60% of the salt consumed at the household level is
 7 adequately iodized. Monitoring of the iodine content in salt is inadequate and enforcement of regulations minimal. Nevertheless, recent changes in the industry provide an opportunity for improving iodization on a sustained basis if complementary activities (e.g., improved salt quality and increased demand) are provided and coordinated to achieve maximum effect and the overall policy settings promote the development of a competitive industry. D. ADDITIONAL CONSTRAINTS TO IMPROVING IODINE STATUS 1.27 There are two other important factors currently limiting the effectiveness of iodine control efforts - the lack of information on the iodine status of the community and inadequate coordination of efforts between ministries. 1.28 Assessing the iodine status of the community. An important factor contributing to this limited impact is the lack of information which would allow efforts to be directed to those areas which are most deficient in iodine and their effects to be evaluated. Current information is misleading and out of date. What is needed now is a series of surveys covering all provinces which provide information on the basis of which kabupaten with low iodine status can be identified. More intensive surveys would then be carried out in kabupaten with low iodine status. This information at both the kabupaten and kecamatan levels could then be used to target interventions more effectively (e.g., intensive monitoring of iodine levels in salt, distribution of capsules). 1.29 Government coordination. To date, the government policy and coordination role in control of IDD has not been well executed. This is due, in large part, to the intersectoral nature of the efforts required, the lack of clear responsibility and accountability within government for control of iodine deficiency and overall policy formulation, the absence of a mechanism for coordination of efforts between the various ministries involved and the private sector and the lack of adequate information on the iodine status of the population. If the renewed efforts to control IDD are to succeed there is an urgent need for substantive coordination of the activities of all groups involved. E. A NEW STRATEGY 1.30 Thus, in addition to confirming the limitations of capsules and the potential of salt, Indonesian experience also points to the need for complementary inputs provided they are effectively coordinated. International experience confirms the need for a clear shift in the strategy for control of iodine deficiency from one in which the _ fa=Ž primary emphasis has been on distribution of capsules with secondary irnportance assigned to iodization of salt to one in which the greatest emphasis is given to salt and capsules used for highly targeted distribution in very specific circumstances. A strategy in which there is increased reliance on iodized salt and targeted use of capsules has five main elements - first, assess and monitor the iodine status of the community in order to provide a basis for targeting efforts to those areas in which the iodine status is low; second, rely on iodized salt as the main means of delivering iodine - this will depend on improved quality of salt production, monitoring the iodine content of salt and enforcing regulations; third, increase demand for iodized salt in areas of low iodine status; fourth, restrict use of capsules to women of child bearing age in areas where iodine deficiency is severe; and fifth, coordinated activities between ministries.

This will involve continued reduction in tariffs, ensuring that PT Garam operates on a fully commercial basis. Assurances on removal of non-tariff restraints to trade in iodized salt and salt for human consumption by December 31, 1998 were received during negotiations.  10 2. PAST AND PROSPECTIVE BANK INVOLVEMENT A. LESSONS LEARNED FROM WORLD BANK PROJECTS AND OTHER INITIATIVES 2.1 IDD Project and Components. Whilst IDD control activities are included in many Bank projects, to date most of these activities have concentrated on surveys of iodine status and procurement of iodized oil. Few, if any, have directly tackled the problem of iodized salt including salt quality, supply and demand for iodized salt, monitoring of the iodine content of salt and enforcement of regulations. 2.2 One partial exception is the "Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Project" for the People's Republic of China which became effective in April 1996. The central strategy of the project is iodization of all salt for human and animal consumption. Implementation of the project requires coordination of several ministries (including industry and health) at three levels of government. The government has established a high level group to coordinate the program in which implementation of the industrial activities is under the control of the Council for Light Industry. Health-related aspects of the program will be carried out by the Ministry of Health. Additional technical assistance will be provided by other donors. As the project has only recently commenced it is still too early to draw lessons for other projects. 2.3 Health and Nutrition projects in Indonesia. The Bank has experience in IDD control in Indonesia through small components in the Second Nutrition and Community Health Project (NCH2) and, in particular, through the ongoing Third Community Health and Nutrition Project (CHN3) where IDD control activities are being carried out at both the central and provincial levels. These activities include IDD surveys, social marketing of iodized salt and provincial level monitoring of the iodine levels in salt. Experience in these projects indicates (a) the need for a national strategy for IDD control which allows for differentiation of approaches according to the local situation. Although IDD occurs in all provinces there is considerable variation between and within provinces pointing to the need for geographic differentiation of strategies. In addition, the salt industry is complex, has many participants, and there is considerable inter-island trade in salt. Whilst East Java is responsible for at least half the total salt produced, seven other provinces also produce salt for human consumption. Consequently, a national perspective of the IDD problem is needed which allows integration of demand, supply and government regulation issues; (b) such a national approach will also need to be inter-ministerial in that the statutory responsibilities for assessing IDD status, and implementation of the various strategies which might be used in control of IDD, is spread across the Ministries of Health, Industry and Trade, and Interior; (c) the inter-ministerial nature of the activities points to the need for a mechanism to coordinate the overall effort; (d) the need to recognize the role of the private sector in the salt industry and the important part it has to play in improved efficiency of salt production and processing; (e) there is an urgent need for information in
 11 all provinces on both the IDD status of the population and the iodine content of salt at the household level; (f) it is important to build on the experience of, and collaborate with UNICEF in IDD control activities. 2.4 In addition, the results of surveys of the iodine status of the community in provinces included in CHN3 are now becoming available. The results of the survey in Maluku have been analyzed. Results for the other four provinces will be available in the latter part of 1996 and will provide a valuable basis for targeting activities in those provinces in the early years of the project while new surveys are carried out in other provinces as a prelude to extension of the targeting approach. 2.5 Thus, it is now clear that whilst the current response through CHN3 has been important, and will provide a solid basis for the initial activities proposed under the IDD project, an expanded and intensified effort is needed if the extent of iodine deficiency is to be reduced. The project proposed here will do that. 2.6 UNICEF has long experience in control of IDD in Indonesia. It has provided support to the GOI for control of IDD for 20 years, originally by donating iodization equipment and iodate, then iodized oil. In recent years UNICEF has worked primarily with MOIT to improve iodization of salt, primarily through improved salt monitoring, marketing campaigns, and community-based efforts using school teachers. The Bank has participated with UNICEF in a discussions with government on IDD since 1990. The monitoring and information, education and communication (IEC) elements of the project proposed here draw on the experience and pilot projects of UNICEF. B. LINKAGE TO COUNTRY ASSISTANCE STRATEGY AND RATIONALE FOR BANK INVOLVEMENT 2.7 The project is consistent with the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Indonesia, which was presented to the Board on March 21, 1995, and the CAS Progress Report discussed by the Board on June 4, 1996. The CAS endorses government's role in establishing a regulatory framework and in supporting decentralization and participation. The design of the proposed project is consistent with the emphasis in the CAS on the importance of human resource development to promote economic growth, competitiveness, and structural transformation, and on a more selective, efficient use of public resources. In particular, the CAS notes that considerable scope exists to improve the quality of health services through better resource use. 2.8 In the last six years the Bank has engaged in a comprehensive dialogue with MOH and Bappenas on the problems of controlling IDD. This dialogue, which recently has been extended to include MOIT and MOHA, has drawn the attention of the government to the need for a comprehensive policy with emphasis on sustainable solutions, the importance of current and reliable information on the IDD status of the population in all provinces, the short term nature of intervention strategies based on iodized oil, and the important potential role of iodized salt. In addition, recent sector work by the Bank has highlighted the problems with GOI's current efforts and concluded that the IDD problem is considerably larger than was previously thought. 2.9 The Bank's comparative advantage in supporting the control of IDD derives not only from the ongoing dialogue and its experience in control of IDD through CHN3. As a result of the Bank's
 12 analysis of both economic and technical issues, it has credibility with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and Bappenas as well as the line ministries involved and is therefore in a position to mediate and facilitate communication across ministries. Other donors, particularly UNICEF, have promoted control of iodine deficiency, especially through social marketing and the MOIT. Apart from its primary focus on a single ministry, UNICEF has been unable to provide the level of resources needed for an Intensified IDD Control Project. In this regard, the Bank is clearly assuming its role as the lender of last resort. 2.10 Consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy, this project will lead to improved quality and efficiency in the health services. Improved iodization of salt will allow the health sector to increase the proportion of the population covered by control activities and eliminate the use of expensive iodine capsules except in those areas where the prevalence of IDD is very high and/or the distribution of salt limited. It will also provide substantial benefits to the poor who are more likely to consume uniodized salt and, therefore, to suffer from iodine deficiency. This project fits well with other ongoing and proposed Bank projects in health, primary education and early child development.

 14 C. PROJECT DESIGN 3.3 The project would have 5 main components, each corresponding to one of the main objectives. 3.4 Component 1. Monitoring iodine status of the community (Total base costs $6.3 million - see Table 4.1 and Annex 7 for details) to include: * IDD surveys and mapping * ongoing monitoring and surveillance of iodine status in the community * operational research 3.5 IDD surveys and mapping of the iodine status of the community. This component has two main aims - to provide an assessment of the extent of the problem and to serve as a basis for targeting capsules. These mapping, monitoring and surveillance aims will be met using the following survey methods. (a) Kecamatan IDD Prevalence surveys. The project will support kecamatan IDD prevalence surveys which will be coordinated from the national level. Data from these surveys will allow mapping of iodine status of the community at the kecamatan level and provide a baseline against which to measure change over time. School children in grades 3-4 will be the indicator group and goiter by palpation the specific indicator. Similar surveys have already been conducted in six provinces (West Java, Central Java, Yogyakarta, NTB, Maluku, Irian Jaya) under the CHN3 project. Comparable surveys will be conducted in the remaining 20 provinces in the course of the project. (b) National IDD survey. Funds will be provided through the project to repeat the survey of iodine status of schoolchildren in all kabupaten at the end of the project to allow impact to be assessed. In addition, levels of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) will be measured in a sample of women of child bearing age to provide provincial estimates of the prevalence of abnormal values. 3.6 Salt consumption survey. Following the successful initiative funded by UNICEF in 1995, the project will support annual monitoring of the adequacy of iodine levels in salt at the household level in conjunction with SUSENAS. 3.7 Operations research. The project will fund operations research to address questions on the determinants of iodine status that arise in the course of implementation. 3.8 Component 2. Increased consumption of iodized salt (Total base costs $3.2 million see Table 4.1 and Annex 7 for details). * mass media campaign to increase consumption of iodized salt * in-depth campaigns in areas which do not respond to media campaign * promotion of iodized capsules in targeted kecamatan.
 15 3.9 Mass media campaign. The project will fund advertising through mass media. An intensive radio campaign, complemented by television, will be undertaken with the express objective of effecting significant change in the percentage of households consuming iodized salt. The success of these campaigns will be tracked every year through SUSENAS data and MOIT surveys in those areas where more intensive monitoring is occurring. 3.10 Promoting capsules. Although the primary vehicle for distributing iodine is salt, in areas which are either isolated or where the level of deficiency is particularly severe, annual capsule distribution may be the only way to improve iodine status in the short- to medium-term. The project will support intensive pre-distribution promotion and publicity to alert populations to upcoming distribution days. 3.11 The demand generation activities will be managed by the Center for Health Education (PKM). However, because much of this activity is similar to a commercial marketing and advertising campaign PKM will subcontract a highly qualified and experienced advertising agency to handle its radio and television spot campaigns and to carry out the formative research required. PKM will, nevertheless, play an important role in orienting both the research and the marketing design. The activities will be coordinated with those of other ministries through the Project Management Team and Bappenas. 3.12 Component 3. Increased supply of iodized salt (Total base costs $8.9 million - see Table 4.1 and Annex 7 for details). This component will involve the following activities: * monitoring of the iodine content of salt * enforcement of salt iodization * promoting a rules-based approach to the industry * improving the quality of salt produced by farmers/sharefarmers * Salt farmers/sharefarmers development program * operations research 3.13 Monitoring the iodine content of salt. The iodine content of salt will be monitored at several points in the salt distribution system with a focus on actions and responses. To minimize data gathering the most intensive and frequent monitoring will occur in those areas where the iodine status of the community is low and/or where the iodine content of salt is inadequate. The elements of the system are as follows - (a) Routine monitoring at production level. The project will fund external monitoring to be carried out by the MOIT who will visit each plant monthly at random to test all brands of salt using principles of lot quality assurance (LQAS) to determine if each brand is adequately iodized. External monitoring will only be carried out in the 70 kabupaten in which are located firms that process more than 500 tons/year. Technical advice to producers and processors to improve the quality of their product will be
 16 available through the Association of Iodized Salt Producers (APROGAKOB) in conjunction with the MOIT. (b) Routine monitoring at market level. The project will fund routine monitoring at the market level where salt will be sampled by brand in all kabupaten. Intensive market monitoring, to be carried out by MOIT, will be carried out in those kabupaten in which the adequacy of iodine levels in salt at the household level is low. In kabupaten where the adequacy of iodine levels in salt at the household level is high, verification monitoring will be carried out by MOH-Directorate of Food and Drug Control. Assessment of the adequacy of iodine levels in salt at the household level will be based on the results of annual monitoring of iodine levels in salt through SUSENAS - see para 3.6. (c) Community-based monitoring. The project will fund qualitative monitoring of iodine levels in salt. This will extend the existing collaboration between UNICEF, the School Teachers Association and the MOIT. Children will bring samples of salt from home to be tested by the teacher. Communities in which the proportion of salt adequately iodized is low will be identified. Constraints at the household level will be investigated by Posyandu workers and corrective action taken. Results will be transmitted to the MOH and the MOIT through the puskesmas. (d) Database of salt processors. The project will fund the upgrading and maintenance by the MOIT of a complete listing of all salt processors. It will include a company and brand profile and will be available to all ministries participating in the project. (e) Data management and analysis. The project will fund entry of data from each of the monitoring activities through the provincial MOIT offices. The information will be transmitted to, and stored in, the MOIT central database on salt production and processing. The database will be accessible to all ministries contributing to it. The project will also provide resources to enable MOIT to produce standard monthly reports on salt production and iodization for each of the ministries involved. 3.14 Enforcement of salt iodization. Control of IDD by iodization of salt will only succeed if an effective enforcement mechanism is in place. This will be achieved by: (a) encouraging self-enforcement by the industry. The project will provide funds for self-enforcement by the industry. The funds will be used to allow the industry, through APROGAKOB, to assist its members to comply, primarily through provision of technical assistance. (b) MOIT will enforce the regulations on the iodization of salt. The project will provide funds for MOIT to evaluate monthly reports on the adequacy of iodine levels in salt at the processing level and follow-up activities. The license of factories receiving 2 warning letters within 6 months will be canceled.
 17 3.15 Strengthening a rules-based approach. The project will provide funds during the first two years of the project for Government to evaluate the current regulations for salt and iodized salt with the aim of placing emphasis on the product rather than the process. This will involve setting minimum standards for salt and iodized salt which are appropriate to the industry in Indonesia and consistent with production of adequately iodized salt. During negotiations assurances were received from Government that a review of existing regulations relating to salt and iodized salt will be carried out by June 30, 1998, and, thereafter, regulations will be updated as necessary to specify minimum standards for salt and iodized salt. 3.16 Improved quality of salt produced. The project will fund extension activities in the major salt producing areas by APROGAKOB and MOIT to assist saltfarmers/sharefarmers with adoption of new techniques and pond design to improve the quality of salt produced. 3.17 Salt farmers/sharefarmers development program. The project will fund activities aimed at two groups of farmers. First, those who are likely to survive as salt producers in a more competitive environment if new technology and management techniques are adopted. Here, the project will fund demonstration trials of improved methods of salt production and integration between salt farming, fisheries and artemia production. Second, those farms which by virtue of location, or other reasons, are unlikely to be competitive salt producers. For this group the project will fund demonstration plots of alternative commodities to be produced including fish and artemia. In addition the project will fund improved weather stations in the major salt fields. 3.18 Operations research. The project will fund operational research to address constraints to production and processing not dealt with so far in Indonesia. Examples include the most effective production techniques for small farmers/sharefarmers to produce higher quality salt from limited pond areas, and factors effecting the rate of decline in iodine levels of salt under various storage conditions. Addressing operational issues such as these will require resources for an active and ongoing operations research effort. The results will be used in determining the annual plans for the project. 3.19 This component will be managed by the MOIT as part of the overall project. The activities will be coordinated with those of other ministries through the Project Management Team and Bappenas. 3.20 Component 4. Targeted Distribution of Iodine Capsules. (Total base costs $9.7 million - see Table 4.1 and Annex 7 for details). The project will fund purchase of iodized oil capsules for distribution in kecamatan where deficiency is particularly severe and the availability of iodized salt is limited. In these areas, capsules will be delivered annually to women of child bearing age through the health system following intensive pre-distribution publicity to increase compliance (see para 3.9). During negotiations Government gave assurances that until completion of the Project, procurement of iodized oil capsules would only be undertaken as requiredfor the carrying out of the Project and that Government will, starting December 31, 1997, carry out annual reviews of the results of the surveys to assess the iodine status of the community and the monitoring of iodine levels in salt to determine whether use of capsules can be reduced in subsequent years.

The activities will be coordinated with those of other ministries through the Project Management Team and Bappenas. 3.22 Component 5. Inter-Ministerial Policy and Program Coordination for Control of Iodine Deficiency (Total base costs $5.8 million - see Table 4.1 and Annex 7 for details) to include: * inter-ministerial coordination of project activities and policy and identification of clear lines of accountability and responsibility * ensuring periodic independent "third party" checks of all data and assessment of the iodine situation in the nation. 3.23 Inter-ministerial coordination. The project will fund activities to improve inter-ministerial coordination. At the central level, control of IDD requires action in at least 4 ministries. Coordination, together with clear lines of responsibility and accountability are vital. This coordination function will be carried out through the National Coordination Committee chaired by Bappenas. At the provincial level, although implementation of programs under this strategy will remain the responsibility of the individual ministries and the private sector, coordination will be carried out by the Ministry of Home Affairs. During negotiations the Government provided assurances that it will establish, by January 31, 1997, a National Iodine Deficiency Disorder Coordination Committee, to be chaired by Bappenas, with terms of reference acceptable to the Bank. 3.24 Independent "third party" reviews. Support will be provided through the project for periodic reviews of all results related to the iodine status of the community, iodine levels in salt and epidemiological information to determine whether the results are consistent and, if not, the reason why and the implications for the project activities. These reviews will be the responsibility of Bappenas. During negotiations Government agreed to carry out periodic independent third party reviews starting October 31, 1998, of the iodine status of the population and the effectiveness of the control program. 3.25 Project Management (Total base costs $3.4 million). The project will fund project management activities, much of which will be concerned with coordination of activities at the national and provincial levels. This would be done through National and Provincial Coordinating Committees to be chaired by Bappenas and Bappeda, respectively. Members of the National Committee will be drawn from MOIT, MOH and MOHA. Of the donors, both UNICEF and the Bank have significant and ongoing involvement in assisting government to control IDD. Their membership on this committee is important to ensure that donor activities are also coordinated as part of the overall IDD control effort. The committee would meet at least each 6 months. Its responsibilities would include: (a) to review annual plans of participating ministries for IDD related activities (b) ensure that activities are coordinated at the national and provincial levels (c) carry out six-monthly review of activities and recommendations to overcome problems identified.

The Project Director will be advised by a Steering Committee chaired by the DG of Community Health with members drawn from MOH, MOIT, MOHA, Bappenas, MOF. During negotiations the Government provided assurances that it will establish, by January 31, 1997, and thereafter maintain within MOH an IDD Project Management Unit, of agreed size and skill mix, under terms of reference acceptable to the Bank. 3.28 Channeling of funds. The activities in the mass medi and in-depth campaigns, as well as the promotion of capsules are based on extensive discussions with Jakarta-based professionals dealing with similar campaigns in an advertising agency, a market research firm and UNICEF. The project will be implemented at both the national and provincial levels as described below (and in the Project Implementation Plan in Annex 10). 3.31 National level. Project activities will include formulation of policy for IDD control, revision of regulations governing the salt industry, improved enforcement of iodization of salt, intersectoral coordination, monitoring of the iodine status of the population and iodine content of salt, and national level activities related to stimulation of demand for iodized salt. 3.32 Implementation of these national level activities will begin as soon as possible. The highest priority will be given to immediately strengthening those activities which will bring about an increase in the proportion of salt which is adequately iodized. This includes monitoring iodine levels of salt at the factory level, provision of technical assistance to those factories found to have inadequate iodization, creation of a combined database incorporating the results of the monitoring, and termination of the license of those processors who persistently produce inadequately iodized salt. In Year I these activities will concentrate on Java, the site of 85 percent of the total salt production and iodization capacity. In the second year the emphasis will shift to the remaining sites of salt production and processing whilst maintaining close surveillance of the situation in Java. 3.33 Provincial level. At the provincial level the main strategy is to target activities. There is considerable variation in iodine status between kabupaten and/or kecamatan. Consequently, the most efficient approach, particularly for the expensive iodine capsules and more intensive IEC and monitoring is to focus activity in those kecamatan in which iodine deficiency is most severe and the degree of iodization of salt most inadequate. EXPECTED BENEFITS 5.1 Recent evidence indicates that up to one-half of the Indonesian population are at risk of iodine deficiency (i.e. live in areas of the country in which the prevalence of goiter is at least 10 percent). In areas where iodine deficiency is endemic the probability of a range of physiologic effects, which include goiter, mental deficiency, deaf-mutism, spastic diplegia, squint, dwarfism, and motor retardation is increased in proportion to the severity of the deficiency. Consequently, there are considerable potential benefits, both public and private, from control of IDD. The private benefits include higher productivity and wages, and increased investment and risk taking. The public benefits derive from reduced costs of medical and custodial care, lower schooling costs resulting from reduced absenteeism and lower grade repetition, and higher educational achievement. 5.2 In principle, translation of these effects into benefits to which can be assigned monetary values would allow comparison with the costs of the intervention. Unfortunately, the lack of field trials that quantify the various benefits limits the application of cost-benefit to this area for Indonesia. However, some illustrative calculations of the effect of control of iodine deficiency can be made. Control of iodine deficiency, through its positive effect on mental development, would be expected to increase productivity and wages over the productive life of the individual. Assuming that this results in a I percent increase in annual wages for the rural population in iodine deficient areas (one-third of the population) the IRR for this project is 17 percent. This calculation is sensitive to the increase in wages assumed with a 5 percent increase yielding an IRR of 29 percent (see Annex I for details). These results are of the same order as those obtained for the benefits of reducing mild iodine deficiency in children in Chile (Correa, 1980). 5.3 Other benefits consequent on the control of iodine deficiency include decreased grade repetition in primary school, improved iodine status of women and reduction in the child care burden as the number of severely disabled is reduced. Overall, the benefits from controlling iodine deficiency considerably exceed the cost. B. POVERTY IMPACT 5.4 This project will contribute to alleviation of poverty in two ways - through its effect on the iodine status of the population and through its effect on salt farmers. The successful control of iodine deficiency will have significant health and human development benefits for the poor. By ensuring that salt is adequately iodized the project will prevent the disability resulting from iodine, itself a factor contributing to low incomes. This will be particularly so for those living in iodine deficient locations and in isolated areas where poverty is frequently more severe and the availability of

The overall effect of this project will favor the poor, particularly those in rural areas, who currently are less likely to have access to iodized salt than those who are better off and/or who live in urban areas. 5.5 Small salt farmers/sharefarmers have low incomes which are falling still further. The overall effect of this project will be to improve incomes of this group, who have not received institutional support in the past, by facilitating exposure to, and adoption of, new management practices and technology aimed at improving productivity of those who continue to produce salt and providing alternate sources of income for those who move out of salt production. 5.6 Giving additional weight, as is advocated by some, to the benefits to the poor and vulnerable groups would increase the overall benefits of this project. C. IMPLICATIONS FOR WOMEN 5.7 This project has two main benefits for women. First, it directly addresses a problem which is more prevalent in women due to the higher requirements for iodine during pregnancy and lactation. As a result, goiter, the primary symptom of iodine deficiency, is more prevalent in females of child bearing ages and they will benefit directly from an improved supply of iodine. Second, reductions in the incidence of disability (cretinism and milder forms) in children will reduce the childcare burden, most of which falls on women. Overall, control of iodine deficiency will have very significant benefits for women. D. This virtuous circle will need to be supported by a credible system of enforcing regulations and overall coordination of the inter-ministerial efforts. The project promotes and strengthens moves to liberalize the salt industry and ensure that iodization occurs; it will provide, for the first time, comprehensive information on the iodine status of the community and the iodine content of salt; and it establishes, again for the first time, a mechanism for coordinating the activities of the various ministries. Each of these activities will strengthen the impact of the project, act to maintain the virtuous circle and increase the likelihood that its effects will continue after the project is completed.

RATIONALE FOR GOVERNMENT INVOLVEMENT IN CONTROL OF IDD There are three reasons for government involvement in the control of iodine deficiency disorders (IDD). First, those who live in iodine deficient areas frequently have difficulty in drawing the connection between iodine deficiency and its consequences. Often they have no access to information about the deficiency from which they suffer or to the supplies of iodine needed to restore their iodine status. Government intervention may be the most cost efficient method of delivering both the information and the iodine. Second, the poor frequently can not or will not pay the higher price for the vehicles governments use to deliver extra iodine, such as iodized salt. Poor women may be particularly vulnerable. Government has a role here through public programs which in effect transfer income to the poor in order to ensure that they have access to the additional iodine needed. And third, there may be significant externalities to be derived from the control of IDD. In areas where iodine deficiency is endemic the probability of a range of physiologic effects, which include goiter, mental deficiency ranging in severity from mild to severe, and a range of neurologic defects (e.g., deaf-mutism, spastic diplegia, squint, and motor retardation) is increased in proportion to the severity of the deficiency. At least some of the costs of caring for those affected must be borne by the society at large. To the extent that this is true control of iodine deficiency will result in externalities. In addition, iodine deficiency limits cognitive development, decreases the public returns to schooling and increases educational costs due to absenteeism, grade repetition and lower achievement. Again, these costs are borne at least in part, by society. And again, controlling iodine deficiency will result in externalities. Overall, there are very significant extemalities to the control of iodine deficiency This rationale and pattern of government involvement is consistent with the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Indonesia, which was presented to the Board on March 21, 1995, and the CAS Progress Report discussed by the Board on June 6, 1996. The control of iodine deficiency is consistent with the emphasis in the CAS on the importance of human resource development to promote economic growth, competitiveness, and structural transformation, and on a more selective,

ESTIMATES OF THE SIZE OF THE PROBLEM The population "at risk" of iodine deficiency is conventionally defined as those people living in areas in which the prevalence of endemic goiter is at least 10 percent, and this definition has been used in Indonesia. Current estimates of the population at risk (those living in areas in which the goiter prevalence is at least 10 percent) are based on the results of the 1980-82 goiter survey. Based on these figures it is estimated by the Ministry of Health that 17 percent of the Indonesian population are living in endemic areas. However, there are many limitations to this estimate due to the sampling procedures used in the 1980/82 survey. Approximately one-quarter of the 3349 kecamatan defined at the time were included in the survey. Kecamatan included in the survey were chosen on the basis of a visit to the market by the local doctor. If at least 5 visible goiters were detected the kecamatan was classified as having endemic iodine deficiency and a survey carried out. Those kecamatan not included in the survey were classified as non-endemic. Thus, to the extent that the "non-endemic" kecamatan do in fact have appreciable levels of iodine deficiency the 1980/82 database is an inadequate tool for estimating prevalence. Because all subsequent surveys to date have been based on the sampling frame set at the time of the 1980/82 survey it is not possible to estimate the extent of this inadequacy for Indonesia as a whole. Recent GOI/Bank analysis for East Java, where additional information is available, indicates that while most (80 percent) of the kecamatan selected on the basis of the 1980/82 survey had a serious iodine problem, there were even more kecamatan with a serious problem amongst those not surveyed. Using the 1980/82 data as the basis for estimating overall prevalence seriously underestimates the size of the problem in Indonesia. Given that the information base is poor, to the point where it is misleading, is it possible to provide even broad estimates of the size of the problem in Indonesia? This question has been approached from two different angles - first, utilizing more recent small scale surveys to determine the extent to which the current information underestimates the size of the population "at risk" of iodine deficiency; and second, based on these revised estimates, to determine the contribution of iodine deficiency to the overall Burden of Disease in Indonesia.

It then achieves a 60 percent margin on costs when salt is sold in Madura for transport to other provinces. A further 10 percent is achieved in Manado when the salt is sold to local processors. A further margin (approximately 30 percent) results when the salt is sold to retailers. Overall, in the provinces where it operates PT Garam operates as a price leader which, through low technology production, inefficient procedures and high margins leads to high prices to the consumer which, in turn, protect other companies from downward pressure on prices and "guarantees" relatively high profits. Tariffs and salt. This high cost structure operates behind some protection from imports. Until early 1996 a 25 percent tariff was levied on salt imported for human consumption. In the May 1996 deregulation package the rate was reduced to 20 percent and is scheduled to fall to 10 percent by 2003. In contrast, there is no tariff protection for imports of high quality industrial salt. Nontariff barriers. There is also a range of nontariff barriers to internal trade. In two provinces the governor has restricted trade through granting privileged access to the province to PT Garam which then processes, iodizes and sells salt thorough local subsidiaries. This approach is taken in the name of guaranteeing that all salt for human consumption is iodized. And, indeed, in these two provinces the proportion of salt which is adequately iodized is high. At the same time, in the absence of competition, the prices for salt tend to be higher. There is also anecdotal evidence of market sharing between the various companies in the larger population centers, such as Surabaya and Jakarta. 6. MONITORING AND ENFORCEMENT Responsibility for the salt industry as a whole rests with the MOIT which, in reality, concentrates on processors and processing in its relations with the industry. It essentially has no interaction with, and provides no support for, salt farmers/sharefarmers. Monitoring the levels of iodine in salt is split between the MOIT and the MOH. Neither ministry allocates adequate resources to this effort, the number of samples collected and analyzed is too few, and the lack of links between the various data sets make it difficult to identify the processor responsible for any sub-standard samples. There has been little attempt at enforcement of regulations even when salt samples are shown to contain inadequate levels of iodine.
 57 Annex 2 Page 8 of 11 The current government approach to the industry is expressed through Kepres 69/1994 which emphasizes the processes which must be used to process salt. The approach specified is capital intensive and would have the effect of giving advantage to the bigger processors and PT Garam. Although the emphasis is on process, there are also specifications for salt quality and iodization levels. The salt quality specifications are higher than are currently produced by many processors, again giving advantage to the biggest processors and the government owned company. This effect is compounded by the low quality of salt produced by the farmers/sharefarmers. Meeting the requirements for processed salt under the Kepres will require multiple washing of most of the salt produced. Under these new regulations, the MOIT licenses processors on the recommendation of the provincial office of the MOIT. Legislation and regulations allowing for cancellation of licenses after 3 warning letters are in place and MOIT has notified the industry of its intention to enforce these in conjunction with the newly issued licenses. 7. THE INDUSTRY IN THE EARLY 1990's In summary, the characteristics of the industry by the early 1990s were similar to those for other highly regulated "essential" commodities in Indonesia, including fertilizer and cement. These included (1) informal marketing arrangements; (2) protection from tariffs; (3) a range of non-tariff steps and barriers restricting free entry and trade in the domestic market; (4) technological stagnation in a technically inefficient industry; and (5) inability to enforce government regulations relating to iodization. (However, unlike fertilizer and cement, the government depends on salt as a component of an important public health program). There was also a floor price for "People's salt" (salt produced by small sharefarmers) operated by PT Garam which was the dominant player in the industry and a resulting rapid increase in the area of land devoted to People's salt; overproduction of low quality salt; and large national stocks of salt held in conjunction with the price support scheme. This salt industry structure was expensive, costs were passed on to the consumer resulting in high prices, a technically inefficient industry produced low quality salt, and the high degree of protection afforded by high tariff and non-tariff barriers insulated the industry from pressures to innovate and keep costs down. The overall result was a low quality, high cost product and inadequate levels of iodization and consumption of iodized salt, partly as a result of the difference in price between raw salt and the processed, iodized and packaged product. 8. RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN THE INDUSTRY In response to increasing concern that the iodine status of the population may be deteriorating and doubts about the effectiveness of control efforts, a number of initiatives
 58 Annex 2 Page 9 of 11 were taken in the early 1990s to remedy the situation. There was renewed emphasis on iodization of salt as the main strategy for control of IDD. In 1992 the floor price was eliminated and no further additions were made to the national "buffer" stock of salt. (Nevertheless, excess capacity remains and there is still a large national stock). In 1994 a Presidential Decree (Kepres) 69/1994, and the associated ministerial decree, reaffirmed the requirement for iodization of all salt for human consumption and specified the ways in which this should be done. There are plans for PT Garam to purchase and wash approximately 300 000 tons of People's salt each year. To this end it will establish, in 1996, 4 washing plants, I each in East Java, Central Java, West Java, and South Sulawesi. In contrast to the past, this expansion will be in conjunction with a joint venture partner and will be only partly financed by the MOF. Additional finance will be obtained from a commercial loan and from cash flows. Commencing in 1996, an international salt firm, in joint venture with a local company, is importing approximately 30,000 tons per year of bulk salt for human consumption. The salt is packaged in Jakarta. Other international firms, from inside and outside ASEAN, are said to be interested in entering the market. There is also an ongoing plan to build a new salt production and processing plant at Kupang in NTT (where the dry season is somewhat longer) with an annual capacity of 650,000 tons industrial product and 100,000 tons high quality table salt. This proposed investment does not seem to have progressed in the last year. The crucial issue here is whether government will promote increased competition in the industry and reduce its effective subsidy to PT Garam. There are signs that this may be happening. Tariffs will be more than halved by 2003. PT Garam is now raising at least part of the finance for expansion through a commercial loan. New players are entering the industry and the government appears to be committed to enforcing the regulations regarding iodization of salt. 9. ISSUES IN THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE SALT INDUSTRY The main issues facing the industry as it develops further are salt quality, the salt farmers, iodization, and monitoring and enforcement. Salt quality. The quality of salt produced in Indonesia is low, a reflection of the low level of technology used by salt farmers/sharefarmers and PT Garam. Much of the people's salt is often of such poor quality that it is not even suitable for iodization. The level of soluble and insoluble impurities and moisture are all high. As a result the raw salt must be washed and dried before it can be satisfactorily iodized and packaged. The lower the salt quality the more processing is required and the greater the losses at this stage. Estimates of losses in processing are as high as 30 percent. Improving the quality of salt produced is an important aspect of sustainable improvement in iodization and requires changing the production techniques used by salt
 59 Annex 2 Page lOof ll farmers/sharefarmers. Within the industry there is little expertise on improved methods of salt production. As a result, improving the quality of salt produced will require international expertise at least in the medium term, to introduce the changes required and a mechanism for effective communication with farmers/sharefarmers. Salt farmers/sharefarmers. (see also Annex 11). This group, to whom MOIT has paid little attention and provided no extension support, poses several policy challenges. They utilize very basic technology and yields are low. Many were drawn into the industry over the period of the unrealistically high floor price scheme resulting in chronic surplus production. The termination of the scheme in 1993, along with the large stockpile and continuing high production, led to a rapid fall in the farmgate price for salt. As a result the welfare of farmers/sharefarmers has fallen. Overall, there is a need to rationalize small-scale production and this should concentrate on allowing the market to set the price of people's salt, and improved quality and productivity. Achieving this end and at the same time improving the possibilities for increasing iodization while providing support to a disadvantaged group of people will involve: - encouraging the development of technically and economically efficient small- scale producers through technological improvements * providing assistance to those who are likely to be unable to survive as salt producers to diversify into other agricultural activities or into non-farm activities. Even though farmers/sharefarmers are the key to improving quality, the MOIT has paid little attention to this group in the past and has no capacity for reaching the farmers/sharefarmers on a regular basis. New approaches, including use of the private sector, will be needed to determine the most appropriate technology for small-scale salt production and to promote its adoption by farmers/sharefarmers. lodization. Regulations calling for iodization of salt have been on the books in Indonesia for 20 years and the total capacity to iodize the salt is adequate. Yet, the government's own salt company, PT Garam, iodizes only 10 percent of its own salt production. lodization of most of the salt produced by PT Garam is carried out, with varying degrees of success, by its subsidiaries and agents in the provinces. Further, monitoring the iodine content of salt is inadequate and regulations mandating iodization of salt for human consumption are seldom enforced. Although responsibility for monitoring and enforcement rests with the both the MOIT and the MOH, the ability to enforce regulations via cancellation of licenses lies with the MOIT. Resources for monitoring in both ministries have been inadequate and has hindered identification of those processors who persistently fail to produce adequately iodized salt. Changes in the structure of the industry. Two recent developments, the termination of the floor price and introduction of Kepres, are already leading to change in the industry. Termination of the floor price for salt has resulted in a sharp drop in the farmgate price of salt from approximately 30 Rp/kg in 1993 to 15 Rp/kg in 1995. It is likely that prices
 60 Annex 2 Page 11 of 11 will continue at this much lower level, partly because the earlier floor price was too high and partly because the new entrants attracted by the high floor price resulted in excess capacity. The falling returns to salt production will force change in the industry and provide an important opportunity for assisting salt farmers/sharefarmers to improve their circumstances through a range of strategies. For those able to survive in a more competitive environment these include technological innovation, improved management of individual farms, consolidation where feasible and, for some, complementary production of other commodities such as fish and artemia'. Other farmers/sharefarmers are more likely to survive by moving out of salt altogether and concentrating on alternate commodities of which fish and artemia are the best prospects. The inability of government to provide institutional support for salt farmers/sharefarmers to date and the limited technological expertise on small-scale salt production will require approaches which are outside those available at the moment. However, the lower prices will also serve as a stimulus for the those who remain in the industry to increase productivity and, provided the information is available, to improve the quality of their product. The new regulations introduced under the Kepres will also lead to changes in the structure of the industry, particularly in processing. Thus, many will not be able to meet the new requirements and will not be licensed. Applications for licenses are currently being considered by MOIT. Preliminary indications are that the number of processors will be reduced from approximately 300 in 1995 to around 70 in 1997 with the smaller operators dropping out. It is likely that the number will fall even further in the first 2-3 years of the regulations as other smaller firms persistently fail to meet the standards for iodized salt. The final number may be as low as 50. As a result, monitoring the iodine content of salt will be easier and the proportion of salt that is adequately iodized will increase. Even though the number of processors will fall competitive pressures in the industry are likely to increase. Tariffs on salt for human consumption are scheduled to continue to fall to 10 percent by 2003 opening the possibility of substantial volumes of imports for human consumption. One international salt firm has established a joint venture with an Indonesian partner and other firms are considering entering the market. The bigger local processors and the international firms will move to improve returns on their investments by increasing market share.  74 Annex 10 Page 1 of 3 INDONESIA Intensified Iodine Deficiency Control Project Project Implementation Plan Project Implementation. The project will be implemented at both the national and provincial levels as described below. National level. Project activities will include formulation of policy for IDD control, revision of regulations governing the salt industry, improved enforcement of iodization of salt, intersectoral coordination, monitoring of the iodine status of the population and iodine content of salt, and national level activities related to stimulation of demand for iodized salt. Implementation of these national level activities will begin as soon as possible. The highest priority will be given to immediately strengthening those activities which will bring about an increase in the proportion of salt which is adequately iodized. This includes monitoring iodine levels of salt at the factory level, provision of technical assistance to those factories found to have inadequate iodization, creation of a combined database incorporating the results of the monitoring, and termination of the license of those processors who persistently produce inadequately iodized salt. In Year 1 these activities will concentrate on Java, the site of 85% of the total salt production and iodization capacity. In the second year the emphasis will shift to the remaining sites of salt production and processing whilst maintain close surveillance of the situation in Java. Provincial level. At the provincial level the main strategy is to target activities. There is considerable variation in iodine status between kabupaten and/or kecamatan. Consequently, the most efficient approach, particularly for the expensive iodine capsules and more intensive IEC and monitoring is to focus activity in those kecamatan in which iodine deficiency is most severe and the degree of iodization of salt most inadequate. Three different packages of services will be targeted to particular kecamatan depending on the severity of iodine deficiency and the adequacy of salt iodization. The introduction of these packages will be phased in various parts of the country. Phasing. The provincial level activities will be phased according to the availability of data, the adequacy of iodine levels in salt and general feasibility considerations. This information on the adequacy of iodine levels in salt is now available by kabupaten from SUSENAS. They indicate that, in general, the levels are most inadequate on Java, then in the eastern provinces and most adequate in Kalimantan and Sumatra. This overall phasing has been adopted for the introduction of provincial activities. Thus, the initial emphasis for provincial activities will be on Java where older surveys have indicated iodine deficiency is a problem and recent SUSENAS information indicates that levels of adequacy of salt are also lowest. In addition, information on the iodine status of the population is now, or soon will be, available at the kabupaten level for West and Central Java and Yogyakarta from surveys being carried out under CHN3. The current project will fund a similar surveys in other provinces in the first 2 years. Attention will turn to the remaining provinces (Kalimantan and Sumatra where existing information indicates that the adequacy of iodine levels in salt is highest) in the second year of the project as surveys of the iodine status of the community are implemented thus allowing the kecamatan level activities to be introduced in these provinces. In these provinces, broader activities
 75 Annex 10 Page 2 of 3 aimed at improving the level of iodization of salt and stimulating demand for iodized salt will have commenced in Year 2. Technical assistance. The project would support modest amounts cf international and local technical assistance, concentrated in the first three years. International technical assistance, estimated at 9 person years, would be directed at improving the quality of salt produced by salt farmers/sharefarmers and at the quality of iodization, demand generation and operational research. Local technical assistance of 30 person years would be used to assist with training modules, demand generation and operational research. Performance evaluation and supervision strategy. Monitoring of project implementation will be the responsibility of the Project Secretariat in conjunction with the National and Provincial Coordination Committees. The implementation progress of the project will be assessed through monitoring activities and formative evaluation using the detailed performance indicators. Additionally, outcome indicators have been identified to guide development impact evaluation. Annual reviews will take place by October of each project year, starting in 1997, and will: (a) analyze the previous year's performance and budget execution against project objectives and indicators; (b) analyze the proposed workplan and budget for the following year; (c) discuss adjustments to be made in the project implementation schedule; and (d) analyze the results of the project evaluation. The proposed workplan and budget for the following year will have been previously defined at the central and provincial levels and contain a detailed description of targets and planned activities (see Annex 5). A comprehensive mid-term review will be conducted to assess project performance and initial impact in light of project objectives, project indicators and government policies. A project implementation completion report is due no later than six months after the closing date of the loan. The report is expected to provide a critical overview of project inputs, processes and outcomes. The report will summarize: (a) project results and impact on the basis of indicators; (b) key project activities and management; (c) lessons learned from project implementation; (d) the project's financial status; and (e) implementation issues and recommendations.
