 77 Annex 11 Page I of 3 INDONESIA Intensified Iodine Deficiency Control Project STUDY OF SALT FARMERS AND SHAREFARMERS Executive Summary This document is a preliminary report on a study of salt farmers and sharefarmers in Indonesia undertaken in April and May of 1996. Its findings rely heavily on a survey of farmers undertaken in three districts of Madura. About 900,000 tonnes of (sometimes called "people's") salt are estimated to be produced annually in Indonesia by small farmers (operating as landowners, leaseholders, sharecroppers and laborers), mainly in the provinces of East Java (of which Madura island is a part, and which accounts for about 45% of total production), West Java, Central Java, South Sulawesi and the NTB provinces. Production technology is very basic and salt yields are low by international standards (e.g. compared to the USA, Australia, India and Brazil), output quality is poor, and farmgate prices and financial returns to salt enterprises are depressed since the ending (in 1993) of a national stock management scheme which sought to maintain floor producer prices. Because of the environmental (i.e. low salinity water) and climatic (i.e. short dry season) conditions in which this salt is produced (and because of the prevailing - i.e. individual small farm, low input/low output - mode of production which has developed in these circumstances) the Indonesian small-scale salt industry is fundamentally uncompetitive in world terms. The small farmers' salt is of very poor quality (about 94% NaCl on average), being contaminated with insoluble materials (mud, sticks, stones from hand harvesting of thin salt crops) and with calcium and magnesium compounds because of the salt evaporation techniques used. A local state company (PT Garam) also produces salt on a larger scale, but uses essentially the same technology as the farmers; there is no other institution in Indonesia responsible for technological innovation or support to the small farmers. Salt produced in this way is of concern to policy makers in Indonesia because the quantities produced on individual farms to not lend themselves to easy iodization, because amounts of the salt produced this way appear to enter local markets without being iodized (even if they go via traders/processors), and because the situation of these farmers is deteriorating as prices continue to fall and other sources of income-earning opportunities are presently limited. Increasing international pressure on domestic producers as a result of Indonesia's membership of world and regional trade bodies and the need to raise farmers' incomes in the absence of support buying (together with a desire to raise output quality) have, therefore, suggested that the industry needs restructuring, with farmers becoming more technically efficient at salt production (where this is possible) and/or more diversified in their range of activities (i.e. in those circumstances where salt cannot be produced more efficiently). The survey of farmers in Madura suggests that the average salt farm size is about 2 hectares, (although most farms are smaller than this - a more typical size would be 1.3 ha) and that
 78 Annex 11 Page 2 of 3 landowners' salt operations are larger than non-owners. The sample included severa! large producers, with areas of salt of 0-30 hectares each. Farms can be several kilometers away from both roads and source of salt water, and have much lower ratios than is usual around the world of 'concentrator' (i.e. evaporation) ponds to crystallizer ponds. Farmers are typically in their forties, have 20 years of salt experience, several years primary education and no secondary education. Farmers have almost no technical support, and access to credit is almost entirely from informal sources, including advances from salt traders. Salt cultivation relies heavily on seasonal labour, with about 5 laboring jobs being created per farm. Average yields are low, at under 60 tonnes per hectare per (five month) season. The estimated 1995 average farmgate (really pondside) price was Rp.1 5-37 per kg (compared to Rp25-35 three years ago). This is consistent with estimates made when the abandonment of the buffer stock scheme was being mooted. On-farm transportation costs (i.e. from pondside to road, and borne by the farmer after sale is agreed) can be considerable, and these reduce farmers' earnings. One-eighth of sampled farmers made no sales in 1995, but preferred to stockpile. Estimated operating profits of salt enterprises are about Rp237,000 per hectare per season if all output is sold; this figure is substantially reduced by any on-farm transportation, by stockpiling over seasons, and for sharecroppers (who receive about 40% of this on average). About two-thirds of farmers' incomes comes from salt production, although about half of farmers appear to have other sources of income (fish farming and capture being most common). The rainfall situation in the wet season (with respect to the respective amounts of precipitation and evaporation) is not clear in Madura, but farmers do not store concentrating brine across seasons, but start each year with fresh seawater. Further, intake seawater is often of low salinity (1 or 2 Degrees Baume only - having been mixed with fresh water from rivers). In these circumstances, water management is poor, with undersaturated brines (from an incorrect ratio of concentrator to crystallizer ponds) being fed to cystallizers (resulting in calcium deposition) and no draining of bittem after salt cystallization (resulting in magnesium deposition). A series of thin salt crops are harvested throughout the season, contaminated with insoluble matter. Individual, small-scale, scattered patterns of cultivation result in high transport costs (because produced salt from ponds is not usually located at roadsides), the intake of low salinity water for many farmers (because many farms are a long distance from the most saline water), and a lack of realization of scale economies (e.g. through the use of machinery) in salt washing, grading, packaging, and iodization. Various options to improve the quantity and quality of salt from small-scale producers are suggested. These primarily involve changing pond ratios to produce a thicker crop of salt in layers, allowing year-round storage of water so as to start the season with more concentrated brine (and
 79 Annex 11 Page 3 of 3 allow movement of saline water between farms), and consolidating farmers' ponds to enjoy design and scale advantages. Largely because of the historical institutional neglect of the industry, the technical and financial viability of these models is not certain, and therefore, their potential applicability to all salt farmers is impossible to predict at present. Options for consolidation are likely to be limited and long-term in nature. The best opportunities for most farmers to diversify their activities away from salt lie in the cultivation of milkfish and in the production of artemia. Models to establish these as enterprises in their own right and also integrated with salt cultivation (e.g. by using ponds for both fish and salt) need to be tested, in association with work already being done by some institutions under the Ministry of Agriculture in Indonesia.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Intensified Iodine Deficiency Control Project is to lower the prevalence of iodine deficiency in Indonesia. This will be achieved through the following components: a) monitoring the iodine status of the community; b) increasing consumption of iodized salt; c) increasing the supply of iodized salt; d) targeted distribution of iodine capsules; and e) inter-ministerial policy and program coordination for control of iodine deficiency.
